story:
• I wrote the original Football Manager.. (1980s)

  • I have created a new version of the game, and players love it!

  • The new match highlights are great fun

  • Please help me make it better still!

Summary - Where it began!

I wrote the original Football Manager game that started the genre. It is considered a classic. Despite it's 35 year age FourFourTwo Magazine rates it in the top 10 Football Manager games of all time.

I re-created it!

By request online I re-vitalised it for mobiles and laptops and called it Football Star Manager. I  added new Match Highlights. People are loving this game, it brings back memories, it is fun, as addictive as the original, and now portable!

I love doing this work, and I want to take it further. 

I have more to do and I need some support

It's been out for a year and I keep making it better. It focuses on the key parts of Football Management, your team, strategy and tactics.

I have lots of ideas and I want next to add Penalties, Free Kicks, and slick passing moves to the highlights.  Here are the current match highlights etc:

Is this game already available?

Yes, you can buy it now, here is a link to all 5 versions, Android, iOS, Windows, Kindle Fire, and Mac OS X: http://bit.ly/playfsm

(I have been working hard!)

I need your help to continue creating fun

I am prolific with ideas and I work hard to get them done. Now I need your help.

I will use the funds for approximately 3 months work plus the work of a graphics artist. 

Everything that is contributed will move the project forward and I will continue as long as I can even if the full funding goal is not reached.

Thank you for even considering taking part, and thank you in advance for anything you can offer. And if you cannot, please spread the word!!

To be honest, all the way through for me, this has been a labour of love, and creativity, and I want to continue. 

Fun perks!

I have tried to make the perks entertaining and valuable, for example

  • Get your original Football Manager cassette inlay signed by me, the author
  • Get a signed print copy of the original artwork painting
  • Get a 1 to 1 Skype interview with me. Ask me the questions about original Football Manager, or the new Football Star Manager, that you want to know! :)

 

About me

I wrote the original Football Manager all those years ago, originally launching it on ZX81 (and TRS80). It became a very successful and popular game, later for Sinclair Spectrum, Commodore 64, BBC Micro, Amstrad CPC, Electron, VIC20 etc. I was known for putting my picture in the ads with my well known beard :). The reason I did that was because I believed in my game and was prepared to back it. 

Well I am "without beard" now but, I have stayed in software engineering ever since, never lost my love of games design and found my skills really came together as I wrote this re-vitalised version of the game, it felt right every step of the way and players have given me great 5 star feedback. They also love my updates which always add to playability and fun in the game.

I have created a Football Management game that feels like fun all the time and is never an effort. With your help I will continue to make it better. 

Kind regards,

 

Kevin Toms

If you would like details:

 

About the Match Highlights

I included Match Highlights in the original Football Manager, which started on the ZX81, when I adapted it to the Sinclair Spectrum. They were quite an innovation at the time and spiced up what was already a very playable game. I did the same thing in the last few months and have included Match Highlights in the Football Star Manager re-creation. But, they are much better, smarter, more interesting and more fun!

Players love this, and now I want to add more spice with penalties, free-kicks, and slicker passing moves! 
 

Isn't it very old? Why do people like it again?

The basis of this game was written 35 years ago, and amazingly people still play that original game today. Why? Because, despite all the technology advances since, the original game scores on playability, fun, and ease of use. On these it stands up today. By re-creating it for mobiles and laptops I have allowed people to once more play a game they loved without the technical limitation of the old machines.

What I have done also is added to the game, making it even better. It keeps the original features and core, after all that was my own design, - and I made it portable and better. 

 

How Football Star Manager, this re-vitalising of the original 80s Football Manager came about

Simply, by request. I mentioned in Autumn 2015 I could re-create the game but for mobiles. I got such a positive reaction the project started. I have now spent 2 years getting the game to this point, half of it full time. All of it done by me, using my own resources. As current players know, I regularly update and improve this game. 

 

What they say about the game so far...

There are many positive comments for example:

From reviews:

"Simply the best. Loved the original and glad it's back. Thank you Kevin"

"The highlights are back. My social life is now over. Brilliant!!"

"Back in the day this is where it all started for me.....can't believe my dreams have come true again....thank you kevin"

"Simple. Addictive. Just how I remember it"

"Loved this back in the day, and the format works really well on a mobile device."

"So simple yet addictive. Pure fun!"

"Brilliant game anyone who loved the original should buy this. Simple to play and far better than being fleeced in game for add ons on other football manager games"

"If you played this as a kid, you'll love it. A great way to kill time on journeys to and from work"

"Blast from the past, had this on the spectrum 48k and was annoyingly addictive, this is also annoyingly addictive..."
Etc...

Please help me make it better still!

story:
Covenant

Covenant is an upcoming SciFi/Dark Fantasy Action RPG set in an alternate history Medieval Europe where a pantheon of Lovecraftian Deities have invaded Earth and have taken up power as the new Gods of Mankind, set for release on PC and Mac OS.

 

The player is tasked with traversing through the domains of each God and liberating them from their oppressive rulers.  The game is inspired by similar action RPG's like Dark Souls or Bloodborne, but also aims to incorporate some strategy and management elements through Mount & Blade-esque battle segments.

Being a solo developer, everything you see on this page has been the result of me working 100% on my own, and while I have the drive and the talent to bring this game to fruition given enough time, in order to expedite development I need to bring on more professionals in the various fields that make up game development (ie. Coders, Musicians, additional Artists, Marketing People, etc.).  I also do most of my work on a pair of broken gaming laptops (not ideal, I've found), and new equipment is going to be necessary to complete development within a reasonable time-frame.

Covenant is simply the type of game that I've always wanted to play myself; a SciFi/Dark Fantasy RPG with some Strategy and Management elements, think Dark Souls meets Mount and Blade with a little bit of base building thrown in for good measure.  And from what I've seen and heard from other gamers and genre enthusiasts, it seems to be the kind of game that a lot of people would want to play, and with financial backing Covenant has the potential to be a great game.  Any amount you might give would make an immense difference in helping to get Covenant's development off the ground.

What We Need

Essentially there are 6 major components to what I need in order to complete Covenant;

  • New Equipment : A proper Workstation-Grade desktop setup, a DSLR Camera for Photo-Scanning, Software Licenses, etc. ($8,000 allocated for these expenses)
  • Hiring Staff : Artists, Programmers, Musicians, etc. ($20,000 allocated for these expenses based on hourly rates, commissions, and work-for-hire costs) I'm looking to keep the dev team fairly small and intimate as not to have too many conflicts between members and ideas.
  • Legal Fees; Mainly to file the proper Copyrights and Trademarks, as well as forming an LLC. ($2,000 allocated for these expenses) 
  • Fulfilling Backer Perks ($3,500 allocated for these expenses)
  • Marketing and Advertising ($3,000 allocated for these expenses)
  • Funds to offset living expenses ($13,500 allocated for these expenses)

If complete funding is not met, the funds that are gathered will be dispersed proportionately based on this model, and cheaper or lower-tier alternatives to services or equipment will be used to cut development costs in order to ensure that Covenant is brought to fruition, even if full funding isn't met.

Any surplus in funding will go towards adding console distribution for the Xbox One, PS4 and Nintendo Switch, and if those stretch goals are met any additional funding will be put towards online multiplayer, so you can pit your army against the armies of other players internationally.

What You Get

Here are a number of different perks for whatever level of contribution you can make

  • $1 - A special thank you with your name in the backers section of the game's credits 
  • $5 - A special thanks, plus a custom message by you in the game's backer credits
  • $10 - A special thanks, message, and a pdf copy of the Art of Covenant digital art book
  • $20 - The previous two perks, plus a digital copy of the game upon release
  • $50 - A physical copy of the game, plus digital art book and soundtrack (credits and message tiers included)
  • $100 - A physical copy of the game with digital art book and soundtrack, plus a character figurine (credits and message tiers included)
  • $150 - A physical copy of the game, physical art book and soundtrack CD, plus the character figurine (credits and message tiers included)
  • $500 - All previous perks plus the opportunity to design your own enemy type to be featured in a special area of the game.

Below is a mockup of the physical packaging, book, and figurine.

Risks & Challenges

Managing a team and budget is always a challenge in terms of completing almost any project.  The greatest challenge will be completing development by my projected date, but I'm more concerned with producing a good game than a bad game completed on time, so even there are any hiccups during development, we'll keep on going until we produce a game we're satisfied with above all else.  I have a plan and a direction in which to take development, and 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute monetarily or don't want to use this platform, you can help by spreading the word about Covenant.  If you're aware of any larger entities that might be interested in backing or helping Covenant reach its development funding goals please help bring the game to their attention, anything helps!  

Want to see more Covenant?

Please visit http://www.loganchitwoodillustration.com/covenant for more media and news related to the development of the game.

Thanks for taking a look at my project!

story:
What is Rytmik Studio?

Simply put, it's a music creation software based around a beautifully simple, yet wonderfully powerful concept. It’s flexible, instant and fun. Create a basic melody in a few steps, compose a great song in a few minutes, and show your musical flare with a whole range of instruments and effects. Rytmik Studio combines a step sequencer and a wavetable synthesizer. All this is supported by a built-in library with over 1200 samples, hundreds of instrument presets and dozens of sample songs. The results of your production can be instantly shared online, or exported to more traditional audio file formats. Rytmik Studio allows you to set different permissions and save songs to the Rytmik Cloud for users to enjoy, from simple playback and rating to remixing and collaborations. Take a song and watch how it evolves as it passes through the hands of more composers and their creative input.

Why IndieGoGo?

We have been developing games and applications for over 19 years. In 2010, we started developing the music application Rytmik for Nintendo DSi. Over time, we added new features and improved existing ones. As Rytmik grew, so did technology, and we took advantage of the more powerful hardware that became available. The latest version, Rytmik Ultimate, is available for Windows, MacOS, Nintendo 3DS, and iPad. We are now currently developing the third generation of Rytmik: Rytmik Studio.

The community behind Rytmik is growing, and we have two clear objectives. Firstly, we would like to complete Rytmik Studio sooner. Secondly, we want to involve the community in shaping the development itself. In today‘s digital age, a togetherness of development and community is essential for everybody. The new version of Rytmik Studio is now at a point where we can accelerate development, and we need your support to achieve this.

Get a stylish Rytmik t-shirt!

DLC Supporter

If we can get at least 10 thousand dollars (our Indiegogo goal). So, all backers who receive the Steam Rytmik Studio reward will also receive Steam's key to the special DLC Supporter. This DLC will not be sold and will no longer be available in the future. EDIT: Even though we did not reach the goal, backers will get this DLC as a thank you for the support. But Supporter DLC will be available during Early Access on Steam. This concerns the following Perks: Early Birds, Composer, DJ, Composer in Shirt, DJ in Shirt, Activist Composer, N-Activist Composer, Workshop, V.I.P. Composer or Philanthropist.

DLC Supporter will include:

  • A unique visualization when playing songs, if you plan to share your music on YouTube, you will easily be able to distinguish yourself from others who purchase the Rytmik Studio later
  • An exclusive demo song that only you can remix
  • 20 additional free slots for Rytmik Cloud

Inspiration

The older geeks out there might still remember “modules”, a once popular music format of the so-called trackers, which were widely used in 16-bit computers. We were also inspired by step sequencers and hardware grooveboxes. When you add a sophisticated synthesizer to the mix, you'll have an idea of what Rytmik Studio combines into one compact music creation toolkit.

 

Why choose Rytmik Studio?

Most of the current music programs are very complex and deep. This is typically reflected in relatively high prices, and often in usability and steep learning curves.

We are heralding the return to the simplicity and playfulness of the first musical programs. Compact control and drag & drop mechanics make it easy to learn and, importantly, to learn quickly. As in previous versions, Rytmik Studio is once again a unique tool for creating chiptunes, game soundtracks, and electronic music. Thanks to the new Rytmik Live mode, Rytmik Studio can now also be used for actual performance purposes.

Rytmik Studio is basically “building blocks” for music. We have built an accessible music kit  that overcomes limiting factors, and makes discovering new procedures a pleasure. Even a beginner can rapidly join the fun with ready-made clips, easily-changed parameters, and the ability to edit existing.

In addition, Rytmik Studio also allows professionals to delve deeper and create a stunning, complex song, completely managing the parameters of a flexible synthesizer and sound engine.

Backward compatibility with Rytmik Ultimate allows you to open a song created in the previous version and enhance it with new features.

Rytmik Studio isn’t intended to compete with software used by major recording studios. Instead, by using modern technology, Rytmik brings back the days when music creation was fun. Rytmik Studio will be simply COOL!

Space collision is the first demo that Martin Linda created in the work-in-progress version of Rytmik Studio. You can listen to it HERE. No external tools or effects were used to create this song. What you hear is 100% Rytmik and direct export from it, plus the imported sample of his voice.

 

Rytmik Features

Basic features (for Rytmik Ultimate and Rytmik Studio)

  • Wavetable Synth – The core of the sound engine is a wavetable synthesizer that generates audio by playing sound samples. Rytmik incorporates 16 of these synthesizers.
  • Drawable Waveform Synth – The wavetable synth enables users to draw short customized samples for unique results.
  • Over 1200 Instrument Samples – drums, bass, percussion, guitars, strings, pianos, melodic instruments, synthetic instruments, pads, vocals, effects, and much more.
  • Step Sequencer – The workspace in Rytmik consists of “clips”. In each clip there are four instruments, along with the note sequences assigned to them. Four clips can play simultaneously. Clips can be assembled into tracks, and are easily moved and copied using intuitive drag & drop technique – as simple as building blocks for music.
  • Modulation Parameters – Every note in the Step Sequencer can determine the pitch and volume of the tone, and can additionally control up to three other parameters of the synthesizer.
  • Sound Effects – Easily implement sound-changing effects with ADSR Envelope, Glide, Digital Delay, Noise Shaper, Sample Offset and Loop Definition.
  • Selection of Sample Songs – Play, analyze, modify and enjoy!
  • Export – Save your finished songs in WAV and MP3 formats.
  • Sharing via Rytmik Cloud – Instantly share Rytmik songs with a community of users and gain access to thousands of other songs. With management tools and a range of permission settings, songs can be locked down or completely open, allowing for a creative world of musical exploration, solo remixing, group collaborations, and much more. Discover, play and rate songs all across the Rytmik Charts.

NEW in Rytmik Studio

  • Advanced Sound Effects – Fine and dramatic sound editing with EQ3, Resonant Filter, Drive, Bright, Modelay, Modulation Matrix, 2× ADSR and 2× LFO with optional target modulation, 4× Send, and Sidechain Compression. ADSR envelopes and LFOs can continuously change a variety of instrument and effect parameters.
  • Automation – Draw automation curves within songs that smoothly control instruments and effects.
  • Instrument Presets – Play with an advanced synth! Choose from hundreds of named presets across multiple categories, and create all-new custom presets.
  • MIDI Input – Rytmik is compatible with standard MIDI keyboards.
  • Sidechain – A must-have tool, especially for contemporary dance and electronic music. Automatically muffle one sound with another (such as a bass with a kick drum). Using these tools makes effects like the “pulsing” in dance music very quick and easy to produce in Rytmik Studio.
  • Global Sound Effects – Using the 2× Stereo Reverb, 2× Stereo Delay, Master EQ and Limiter, each instrument can be sent into two reverbs and two delays. From short and simple sound you can create a long vibrant range, or simply deliver the drum width and space. The final output of the sound engine can be further adjusted by the equalizer. Dynamics is controlled by a limiter (also works in multiband mode).
  • Custom Samples – Rytmik Studio includes a generous number of samples, and also allows you to import new ones freely. Record vocals, instruments and other sources, and seamlessly add these samples into the custom library.
  • Live Performance – Rytmik Studio Live Mode is specially designed for stage performance. Quickly and dynamically change and control songs play, and take full control of effects directly on groups of instruments.

 

How Rytmik Studio works

For a detailed idea of how the program works, we have prepared a new sound engine scheme HERE, and for comparison the previous version is HERE.

Rytmik Live

Rytmik Studio Live Mode is specially designed for stage performance. Quickly and dynamically change and control track play, and take full control of effects directly on groups of instruments. Create – Rehearse – Perform!

 

Community and Rytmik Cloud

The first Rytmik was released in 2010, composers have mainly been publishing their work through YouTube videos, even despite the fact that recording Nintendo DSi was a major technical complication. Rytmik Cloud was launched in 2015 as a dedicated cloud storage solution where composers can share, rate, and edit each other’s works. At Cinemax, we also feature the most interesting songs every month, airing them on a YouTube channel. Check out  the Featured Songs! We genuinely listen to every published piece, music is in our blood. The community has also prepared a continuous stream of music compiled from the best songs. Join in and listen to featured songs over the internet with Rytmik Radio, and for those who want to get acquainted with all the songs (that’s over 7,300!), there's the free Rytmik Player. Music is for sharing. Hear it, rate it, live it!

History of Rytmik

First Generation (2010)

It all started in 2010, when we released the first version on the Nintendo DSiWare platform. The application became popular very quickly. The Nintendo DSi console only had 16MB RAM, so it wasn’t possible to add new instruments to expand on the previous version. Instead, we released new versions that focused on different musical styles. Each version always included new features, and over the course of several years we released five editions: Rytmik, Rytmik: Rock Edition, Rytmik: Hip Hop King, Rytmik: Retrobits and Rytmik: World Music.

 

Second Generation (2015)

Moving to more powerful platforms has allowed us to improve the sound engine and add more features. The philosophy of Rytmik is based on the immediate display of parameter changes. All instruments are instantly available – they are loaded into memory when the application is started. With the transition to new platforms (PC, Mac, Apple iPad, Nintendo 3DS), the limited memory restriction disappeared. Rytmik Ultimate released in 2015, and contains most of the previous versions. In addition, two instrument expansions (or “DLCs” as they’re often known) are available for the desktop version. The same applies for the Rytmik Ultimate Complete version for iPad. The total number of music samples has now reached 1230. In addition, there are 400 words sampled by a robotic voice and a female voice. Rytmik Ultimate also delivered the unique way to share songs with the introduction of Rytmik Cloud. The community of composers has publicly shared more than 7300 songs across platforms! Every composer can offer their own songs for editing, and can of course contribute to other remixes.

Evolution

Check out the 8 year evolution of Rytmik in detail HERE.

Third Generation (2017)

Rytmik Studio. That's what we are working on, and you can now support it. The jump between the second and the third generation is huge. For more specific information, please see the list of features and the description of the internal architecture of our sound engine. We are currently developing this version for PC and Mac. It will be available on Steam in Early Access later this year. The final version of Rytmik Studio will be available in 2018.

History of CINEMAX

The studio was founded in 1998. In its history, it has fully developed and contributed to games and applications for PC, Nintendo, iOS and Mac. Titles include the RPG Inquisitor, arcade game Gumboy Crazy Adventure, and of course, the complete Rytmik franchise. More information at http://cinemax.cz.

 

FAQ

 

When will the final version be ready?
Rytmik Studio for PC / Mac will be released in 2018. Early Access is scheduled for late this year.

How much Rytmik Studio will be on Steam?
Rytmik Studio will be priced at 27.99 EUR / 29.99 USD and the Rytmik Live expansion will be 7.99 EUR / 7.99 USD.

Are you planning a Nintendo Switch version?
Yes. The version for Nintendo Switch will be released in 2018.

Is it possible to use the songs created in Rytmik Studio for commercial purposes?
If you are the author of the music, then nothing prevents you from doing so. You can use Rytmik, for example, for making your own album, adding audio to videos, making a soundtrack for a YouTube channel, creating effects and tunes for a computer game, etc. The use of a cover version or a remix of foreign songs is governed by classic copyright. Please note that if you are not the author of the material, then we advise that you request the owner’s permission prior to any commercial usage.

Are you planning for PS4 or Xbox ONE versions?
The Rytmik application contains a large number of controls is on a very small area. This is ideal for touch control navigation. Keyboard and mouse controls are also very effective. Implementing similar usability for home consoles is not quite as intuitive, and that is why we do not plan to release on these platforms yet, but we definitely open to doing so in the future.
story_txt:
What is Rytmik Studio?
Simply put, it's a music creation software based around a beautifully simple, yet wonderfully powerful concept. It’s flexible, instant and fun. Create a basic melody in a few steps, compose a great song in a few minutes, and show your musical flare with a whole range of instruments and effects. Rytmik Studio combines a step sequencer and a wavetable synthesizer. All this is supported by a built-in library with over 1200 samples, hundreds of instrument presets and dozens of sample songs. The results of your production can be instantly shared online, or exported to more traditional audio file formats. Rytmik Studio allows you to set different permissions and save songs to the Rytmik Cloud for users to enjoy, from simple playback and rating to remixing and collaborations. Take a song and watch how it evolves as it passes through the hands of more composers and their creative input.

Why IndieGoGo?
We have been developing games and applications for over 19 years. In 2010, we started developing the music application Rytmik for Nintendo DSi. Over time, we added new features and improved existing ones. As Rytmik grew, so did technology, and we took advantage of the more powerful hardware that became available. The latest version, Rytmik Ultimate, is available for Windows, MacOS, Nintendo 3DS, and iPad. We are now currently developing the third generation of Rytmik: Rytmik Studio.
The community behind Rytmik is growing, and we have two clear objectives. Firstly, we would like to complete Rytmik Studio sooner. Secondly, we want to involve the community in shaping the development itself. In today‘s digital age, a togetherness of development and community is essential for everybody. The new version of Rytmik Studio is now at a point where we can accelerate development, and we need your support to achieve this.
Get a stylish Rytmik t-shirt!



DLC Supporter
If we can get at least 10 thousand dollars (our Indiegogo goal). So, all backers who receive the Steam Rytmik Studio reward will also receive Steam's key to the special DLC Supporter. This DLC will not be sold and will no longer be available in the future. EDIT: Even though we did not reach the goal, backers will get this DLC as a thank you for the support. But Supporter DLC will be available during Early Access on Steam. This concerns the following Perks: Early Birds, Composer, DJ, Composer in Shirt, DJ in Shirt, Activist Composer, N-Activist Composer, Workshop, V.I.P. Composer or Philanthropist.
DLC Supporter will include:


A unique visualization when playing songs, if you plan to share your music on YouTube, you will easily be able to distinguish yourself from others who purchase the Rytmik Studio later

An exclusive demo song that only you can remix
20 additional free slots for Rytmik Cloud



Inspiration
The older geeks out there might still remember “modules”, a once popular music format of the so-called trackers, which were widely used in 16-bit computers. We were also inspired by step sequencers and hardware grooveboxes. When you add a sophisticated synthesizer to the mix, you'll have an idea of what Rytmik Studio combines into one compact music creation toolkit.
 
Why choose Rytmik Studio?
Most of the current music programs are very complex and deep. This is typically reflected in relatively high prices, and often in usability and steep learning curves.
We are heralding the return to the simplicity and playfulness of the first musical programs. Compact control and drag & drop mechanics make it easy to learn and, importantly, to learn quickly. As in previous versions, Rytmik Studio is once again a unique tool for creating chiptunes, game soundtracks, and electronic music. Thanks to the new Rytmik Live mode, Rytmik Studio can now also be used for actual performance purposes.
Rytmik Studio is basically “building blocks” for music. We have built an accessible music kit  that overcomes limiting factors, and makes discovering new procedures a pleasure. Even a beginner can rapidly join the fun with ready-made clips, easily-changed parameters, and the ability to edit existing.
In addition, Rytmik Studio also allows professionals to delve deeper and create a stunning, complex song, completely managing the parameters of a flexible synthesizer and sound engine.
Backward compatibility with Rytmik Ultimate allows you to open a song created in the previous version and enhance it with new features.
Rytmik Studio isn’t intended to compete with software used by major recording studios. Instead, by using modern technology, Rytmik brings back the days when music creation was fun. Rytmik Studio will be simply COOL!

Space collision is the first demo that Martin Linda created in the work-in-progress version of Rytmik Studio. You can listen to it HERE. No external tools or effects were used to create this song. What you hear is 100% Rytmik and direct export from it, plus the imported sample of his voice.
 
Rytmik Features
Basic features (for Rytmik Ultimate and Rytmik Studio)


Wavetable Synth – The core of the sound engine is a wavetable synthesizer that generates audio by playing sound samples. Rytmik incorporates 16 of these synthesizers.

Drawable Waveform Synth – The wavetable synth enables users to draw short customized samples for unique results.

Over 1200 Instrument Samples – drums, bass, percussion, guitars, strings, pianos, melodic instruments, synthetic instruments, pads, vocals, effects, and much more.

Step Sequencer – The workspace in Rytmik consists of “clips”. In each clip there are four instruments, along with the note sequences assigned to them. Four clips can play simultaneously. Clips can be assembled into tracks, and are easily moved and copied using intuitive drag & drop technique – as simple as building blocks for music.

Modulation Parameters – Every note in the Step Sequencer can determine the pitch and volume of the tone, and can additionally control up to three other parameters of the synthesizer.

Sound Effects – Easily implement sound-changing effects with ADSR Envelope, Glide, Digital Delay, Noise Shaper, Sample Offset and Loop Definition.

Selection of Sample Songs – Play, analyze, modify and enjoy!

Export – Save your finished songs in WAV and MP3 formats.

Sharing via Rytmik Cloud – Instantly share Rytmik songs with a community of users and gain access to thousands of other songs. With management tools and a range of permission settings, songs can be locked down or completely open, allowing for a creative world of musical exploration, solo remixing, group collaborations, and much more. Discover, play and rate songs all across the Rytmik Charts.

NEW in Rytmik Studio


Advanced Sound Effects – Fine and dramatic sound editing with EQ3, Resonant Filter, Drive, Bright, Modelay, Modulation Matrix, 2× ADSR and 2× LFO with optional target modulation, 4× Send, and Sidechain Compression. ADSR envelopes and LFOs can continuously change a variety of instrument and effect parameters.

Automation – Draw automation curves within songs that smoothly control instruments and effects.

Instrument Presets – Play with an advanced synth! Choose from hundreds of named presets across multiple categories, and create all-new custom presets.


MIDI Input – Rytmik is compatible with standard MIDI keyboards.

Sidechain – A must-have tool, especially for contemporary dance and electronic music. Automatically muffle one sound with another (such as a bass with a kick drum). Using these tools makes effects like the “pulsing” in dance music very quick and easy to produce in Rytmik Studio.

Global Sound Effects – Using the 2× Stereo Reverb, 2× Stereo Delay, Master EQ and Limiter, each instrument can be sent into two reverbs and two delays. From short and simple sound you can create a long vibrant range, or simply deliver the drum width and space. The final output of the sound engine can be further adjusted by the equalizer. Dynamics is controlled by a limiter (also works in multiband mode).

Custom Samples – Rytmik Studio includes a generous number of samples, and also allows you to import new ones freely. Record vocals, instruments and other sources, and seamlessly add these samples into the custom library.

Live Performance – Rytmik Studio Live Mode is specially designed for stage performance. Quickly and dynamically change and control songs play, and take full control of effects directly on groups of instruments.

 
How Rytmik Studio worksFor a detailed idea of how the program works, we have prepared a new sound engine scheme HERE, and for comparison the previous version is HERE.Rytmik LiveRytmik Studio Live Mode is specially designed for stage performance. Quickly and dynamically change and control track play, and take full control of effects directly on groups of instruments. Create – Rehearse – Perform! Community and Rytmik CloudThe first Rytmik was released in 2010, composers have mainly been publishing their work through YouTube videos, even despite the fact that recording Nintendo DSi was a major technical complication. Rytmik Cloud was launched in 2015 as a dedicated cloud storage solution where composers can share, rate, and edit each other’s works. At Cinemax, we also feature the most interesting songs every month, airing them on a YouTube channel. Check out  the Featured Songs! We genuinely listen to every published piece, music is in our blood. The community has also prepared a continuous stream of music compiled from the best songs. Join in and listen to featured songs over the internet with Rytmik Radio, and for those who want to get acquainted with all the songs (that’s over 7,300!), there's the free Rytmik Player. Music is for sharing. Hear it, rate it, live it!History of RytmikFirst Generation (2010)It all started in 2010, when we released the first version on the Nintendo DSiWare platform. The application became popular very quickly. The Nintendo DSi console only had 16MB RAM, so it wasn’t possible to add new instruments to expand on the previous version. Instead, we released new versions that focused on different musical styles. Each version always included new features, and over the course of several years we released five editions: Rytmik, Rytmik: Rock Edition, Rytmik: Hip Hop King, Rytmik: Retrobits and Rytmik: World Music. Second Generation (2015)Moving to more powerful platforms has allowed us to improve the sound engine and add more features. The philosophy of Rytmik is based on the immediate display of parameter changes. All instruments are instantly available – they are loaded into memory when the application is started. With the transition to new platforms (PC, Mac, Apple iPad, Nintendo 3DS), the limited memory restriction disappeared. Rytmik Ultimate released in 2015, and contains most of the previous versions. In addition, two instrument expansions (or “DLCs” as they’re often known) are available for the desktop version. The same applies for the Rytmik Ultimate Complete version for iPad. The total number of music samples has now reached 1230. In addition, there are 400 words sampled by a robotic voice and a female voice. Rytmik Ultimate also delivered the unique way to share songs with the introduction of Rytmik Cloud. The community of composers has publicly shared more than 7300 songs across platforms! Every composer can offer their own songs for editing, and can of course contribute to other remixes.EvolutionCheck out the 8 year evolution of Rytmik in detail HERE.Third Generation (2017)Rytmik Studio. That's what we are working on, and you can now support it. The jump between the second and the third generation is huge. For more specific information, please see the list of features and the description of the internal architecture of our sound engine. We are currently developing this version for PC and Mac. It will be available on Steam in Early Access later this year. The final version of Rytmik Studio will be available in 2018.History of CINEMAXThe studio was founded in 1998. In its history, it has fully developed and contributed to games and applications for PC, Nintendo, iOS and Mac. Titles include the RPG Inquisitor, arcade game Gumboy Crazy Adventure, and of course, the complete Rytmik franchise. More information at http://cinemax.cz. FAQ When will the final version be ready?Rytmik Studio for PC / Mac will be released in 2018. Early Access is scheduled for late this year.How much Rytmik Studio will be on Steam?Rytmik Studio will be priced at 27.99 EUR / 29.99 USD and the Rytmik Live expansion will be 7.99 EUR / 7.99 USD.Are you planning a Nintendo Switch version?Yes. The version for Nintendo Switch will be released in 2018.Is it possible to use the songs created in Rytmik Studio for commercial purposes?If you are the author of the music, then nothing prevents you from doing so. You can use Rytmik, for example, for making your own album, adding audio to videos, making a soundtrack for a YouTube channel, creating effects and tunes for a computer game, etc. The use of a cover version or a remix of foreign songs is governed by classic copyright. Please note that if you are not the author of the material, then we advise that you request the owner’s permission prior to any commercial usage.Are you planning for PS4 or Xbox ONE versions?The Rytmik application contains a large number of controls is on a very small area. This is ideal for touch control navigation. Keyboard and mouse controls are also very effective. Implementing similar usability for home consoles is not quite as intuitive, and that is why we do not plan to release on these platforms yet, but we definitely open to doing so in the future.

story:
UPDATE: "Through the Time Vortex" Stretch Goal

I have added a stretch goal for Star Explorers called "Through the Time Vortex."  Since Open Galaxy Exploration games are now fairly common, I've decided to add a brand new game mechanic that allows the player to explore the past, present and future of each star system.  This feature will only be added if the $25,000 stretch goal is reached.  Stay tuned for an updated video demonstrating this revolutionary game mechanic, and look out for some new perks (coming soon) to help facilitate this concept!  See the most recent update for more details: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/star-explore...

A Galaxy Generator

In a future where Earth has been destroyed, humanity hangs in the balance.  Star Explorers is a game that generates a galaxy for the player to explore, map and survive (or not) with old-school first-person game mechanics.

The Star Explorers universe is not a friendly one however, so the player must learn to navigate its pitfalls and difficulties, while risking it all to find a new home for humanity.

I believe that art, fiction and games can inspire people in addition to entertaining.  Since one of my passions is space travel and exploration, I want to use my art to help inspire our younglings to shoot for the stars!

Gameplay

Star Explorers allows the player the full freedom to explore, while offering a main quest that supplies the game's overall story:

  • Travel to distant stars
  • Land on and explore a variety of planets
  • Collect fuel, weapons and other resources in order to progress deeper into the galaxy
  • Upgrade your space suit in order to safely land on planets whose conditions are too extreme
  • Encounter aliens, both friendly and hostile, and engage in combat if necessary
  • Trade with friendly aliens or with the mothership, a full inventory system allows the player to manage items
  • Explore cave systems and other unique locations
  • Complete randomly generated quests
  • Player health, suit condition and a depleting air tank must all be carefully managed in order to survive
  • Heat, cold, radiation, acids and other hazards must be contended with while exploring alien environments

    Game Development

    Star Explorers is already a working prototype, but I need help polishing and completing it for full release:

    • Game development is a time consuming process, which requires one's full concentration.  All the funds would go towards helping me to keep focused on completing the game in a timely manner
    • Easy to play, but difficult to master, Star Explorers will offer a unique, retro styled space game, with old-school game-play mechanics
    • While it may appear to be a "shooter" game on the surface, the focus of the game is really on exploration and discovery
    • A crafting system will be added, allowing the player to create items otherwise unavailable in the Star Explorers universe
    • New planet features, like weather effects, and a wider variety of terrain features will be added to make each world a unique experience

    Risks & Challenges

    When I do complete the game, it MAY NOT unite humanity in a global effort to explore the galaxy.  This is up to everyone else, not just me. 

    If the game does not fulfill its purpose of creating peace on earth and a galaxy wide civilization, I will of course have to come up with another project to accomplish that goal

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you don't feel like you can contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

      • Some people don't play Windows games.  That's okay, it doesn't mean they are bad people.  However, you'd be surprised that hundreds of millions of people use Windows, and a significant percentage of them play video games. 
      • By sharing this project with your friends, you may send it to someone who has always been lookign for a game like this.  Sharing is caring, and it's free, so please share!
      • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

      Thank you!

By sharing this project with your friends, you may send it to someone who has always been lookign for a game like this.  Sharing is caring, and it's free, so please share!
Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you!

story:
The Story Behind Apocalypse

One hundred years ago all hell broke loose, literally. Massive planar gates appeared and hordes of what looked like angels and demons poured through, to wage war on each other with humanity caught in the middle...

Mankind struggled greatly in the war. Angels used us as demon fodder, while the demons enslaved us. Though in some ways we had greater technology, physically we were weak in comparison. The best scientists at Genetix Corp. began working on a mutagen to make the common man into a juggernaut. Instead, what we got were diseased humans with an inability to feel pain, an endless rage, and a taste for flesh....

With our armies decimated, and cities ravaged by the sickness, the world leaders decided that if we can't win, no one wins. Nuclear weapons were detonated in all the plagued cities, and at all the planar gates. The war was over, and mankind clung to life in a new world fraught with danger...

In 2011, Cody Bellinger began the construction of a new tabletop RPG system - one focused on realistic play, exciting roleplaying, and gritty adventure - which he named Apocalypse. He began his work with influences from many other games and systems, including Dungeons and Dragons, Paranoia, and Fallout, but the first version of the product he unveiled was a creature entirely of his own making. With the help of his gaming circle, he began to revise and refine the system through discussion and playtesting, expanding it to a set of rules that could be used in a variety of ways in multiple settings.

Unfortunately, tragedy struck in January 2013 as Cody unexpectedly passed away due to an aortic hemorrhage at only 23 years of age. The gaming group splintered due to the tragedy, and no progress was made on the game, with the pain of Cody's loss too near to the hearts of those who knew him.

In April of 2015, knowing that Cody would want his game played, one of the regular gamemasters of the previous group took the effort to recover Cody's documentation and begin his work again, discussing the rules and settings not only with the previous gaming group, but with a new group that had grown in the intervening years, and restarted playtesting. Combining the documents that Cody had already constructed with notes and thoughts shared through private messaging prior to Cody's untimely death, refinement and development began anew.

With permission from Cody's mother (who, in her own right, has always acted as Group Mom for this myriad group of 20-somethings), we hope to complete the production of Apocalypse and the publication of the new system, both as a memorial to Cody's work and a fresh new take on d20 tabletop gaming for the gaming community. Now we just need your help to make this project of Cody's into a legacy.

The Impact

Apocalypse is a d20 game, but it's unlike any other popular d20 game currently on the market. While it contains elements of this staple of tabletopping that will be familiar to many in the community, it not only brings a fresh, new setting into ready availability, but is designed around real-world actions, effects, and consequences.

Apocalypse is played in the post-apocalyptic world following the events described above, and as such, is a challenging, exciting, and potentially lethal system. Whether you're dealing with shotgun-toting raiders in trucks or you're going toe to toe with a demon behemoth, every choice has the potential to bring dire consequences or great rewards. 

With a new approach to weapon, armor, and character design mechanics comes a laundry list of potential combinations of randomized mutations, class-based powers, and unique abilities. Even the landscape can prove dangerous, as radiation effects and environmental shifts due to the apocalypse can surprise even the most careful adventurers.

Apocalypse mechanics use  a logical, real-world approach to armor functionality (lessening and abating damage received rather than simply making a character harder to hit), weaponry (do you want the shotgun, or the missile launcher?), vehicles, basic equipment, and more. 

This kind of ingenuity of design is not limited just to the setting, The basic rules of the system and its integral workings bring a new perspective into tabletop RPGs, with aspects of the system designed to make actions, story, and even equipment and gear not only more logical, but easier to work with, easier for beginners to understand, and more realistic, allowing for deeper immersion and abundant excitement for players. The flexibility of the system itself also allows for more creative actions, allowing players to be simplistic and straightforward, or even take inspiration from action movie heroes and tropes.

The storyline is well-developed and its seamless integration with the system allows for players to build their own style of play without being disruptive, whether they're focused mainly on the combat aspects and mechanics of the game or on the roleplaying aspects of tabletop gaming.

Apocalypse is the new tabletop that the gaming community needs, and will provide hours, days, or even years of fun to its players.


What Makes Apocalypse Different?

There are a lot of facets that make Apocalypse revolutionary when it comes to tabletop gaming. Obviously, we'd like to keep some of those things back for release so that people who acquire a set of books post-publication (either through a donation perk or through purchase) will have new discoveries to make, but here are some of the awesome parts of what sets Apocalypse apart:

  • Apocalypse has a well-developed, in-depth setting. It contains fully fleshed out stories, NPCs with years of background, and an explanation for anything and everything the players may encounter - but the things the players encounter are varied, story-rich, and detailed.
  • The setting is also highly immersive. While other games give you cool abilities, strange powers, and world-shaking items, Apocalypse is driven on making you feel these things are plausible. Through simplicity and the reality-based design of the mechanics and setting, Apocalypse doesn't have the issue of many other tabletop games where the abilities seem too far-fetched for player grasp and comprehension. Players could even start the game as literal copies of themselves, if they really wished. However, powers and abilities are still fantastical, adventurous, and powerful enough to make the game fun.
  • Another major facet of the Apocalypse system is that it's highly adaptable. Whether the concern is with adaptability to GM designs, player-created situations, or even other setting designs, the system is designed in a way to allow it to be catered to anyone's preferences.
  • Similarly to the system itself, classes and abilities are highly customizable. There is no “best build,” or preferred class design. All of the characters are unique, and even part of the system is designed to ensure this, as character mutations are acquired through random rolls by the GM.
  • Mutations themselves are a definite point of interest, because Apocalypse has a list of possible mutations rivaling comic book worlds, but all are designed in such a way to be useful and usable in the game, and the mechanics allow them to function in highly plausible ways.
  • The fact is, Apocalypse is meant to be played much like an action movie. From shoving a shotgun down a demon's throat, to playing hot potato with a live semtex grenade, the system is built to handle any creative playing idea that players come up with, or that a GM wants to throw in.

These are just a few of the unique aspects that set Apocalypse apart, and hopefully they're attractive features for potential users. People who wish to keep up with some of the more detailed aspects of the system's construction and development are also free to follow the Apocalypse team Facebook, Twitter, and Tumblr blog.


What We Need & What You Get

While $50,000 may seem like a lofty goal, we have some pretty big plans to make Apocalypse into what Cody originally envisioned. We hope to produce and publish a full-length, hardback Apocalypse Core Book on a wide scale, complete with illustrations, information about the rules, the methods of play, the classes, and a full exposition of the factions, settings, and ongoing events of the world of Apocalypse. If we exceed that goal, we'll even begin working on supplemental materials immediately.

  • A major part of our planned budget is for illustrations, both sketched and fully detailed color images. With around 120 images planned, this part of our budget is roughly $15,000.
  • Another important aspect of a core rulebook is the cartography. From setting topography and cityscapes to detailed graphs and dungeons, maps are an integral component of any good tabletop RPG. We plan to hire the best cartographer(s) we can afford, to add these important elements. This part of our budget is also set at $15,000.
  • Of course, publication is a major aspect of our plan for Apocalypse. We hope to self-publish through a respectable publishing agency that focuses on game publication. To that end, we have set aside $5,000 in our budget based on our research into publishers and the packages offered by the company we hope to engage.
  • Writing and editing costs are not inexpensive, and while Cody began fleshing out the setting, there is still much to be done. Part of the production team is already made up of freelance writers and editors, and so we hope to gain their full focus on this project - but that comes at the expense of any other projects which they might otherwise undertake. We hope to use $5,000 to $10,000 to fairly compensate them for their time and efforts exclusively on this project, as well as the time and efforts of the R&D team and designers.
  • The remaining $5,000 to $10,000 of the original $50,000 goal will be used to trademark and copyright the Apocalypse game, setting and related materials, as well as being used for marketing beyond the original marketing materials granted by the publication company's package. Any remainder will be used to offset the cost of playtesting, including the printing of pre-publication manuscripts and materials, project-specific transportation costs, and other assorted project-specific costs.
That's how our plan for the money usage breaks down, but we also plan to provide our contributors with some fun perks for contributions.  Contributors of various levels can get the following awesome rewards:

  • An NPC designed according to your specifications (within the game rules) and placed permanently in the setting of Apocalypse.
  • A hardback copy of the Apocalypse Core Book from the first edition printing, signed by the development leads (even including a copy of Cody's signature).
  • An unsigned hardback copy of the Apocalypse Core Book 
  • A 36" x 24" laminated color poster of the Apocalypse Core Setting map.
  • A Township in the Apocalypse Core Setting named according to either your name or your choice of name (within the reasonable confines of the setting).
  • Your name in the Design Motivators section of the Apocalypse Core Book credits.
  • A PDF copy of the Apocalypse Core Book.
  • Your name in the Contributors section of the Apocalypse Core Book credits.
  • Your name in the Special Thanks section of the Apocalypse Core Book credits.
We also have plans in place for Stretch Goals and new Perks for Stretch Goal Completion, which we will unveil at appropriate times during the campaign.

Risks & Challenges

With any ongoing project, there are natural challenges and obstacles to overcome, and in this aspect, Apocalypse is no different.

  • The fact is, Apocalypse is a d20 system. There are many others, and one of the challenges we hope to overcome with the help of this campaign is that Apocalypse is being birthed into a field of competition with long-established systems of other types. We hope to use part of the money raised by this campaign, as mentioned, to aid in marketing both pre- and post-publication.
  • In the same vein, exposure is a major factor. Part of the reason our publication budget is so high (and may even end up taking a larger portion of the funds than we've already planned) is because we want to make sure that we start out with enough copies of the first edition of the Apocalypse Core Book to have a decently wide original distribution base.
  • While Cody designed something great in the Apocalypse system, he wasn't the best at organizing and fully updating his material. It has already taken countless hours and multiple people working very hard to re-organize the things that he left us, as well as incorporating the various private messages, notes, and random memories we have from gaming sessions into the rules and setting. This effort will be constant and ongoing, and poses a difficult challenge to all the designers and writers. This challenge and the time and effort to overcome it will be aided not only by the fact that we have several professional writers in the development team, but also they will be able to devote more time and effort if they are not sacrificing income to do so through payment from the campaign.
  • Playtesting is an important aspect of the development process. From its inception, Apocalypse has been best refined by playing short campaigns and game sessions to test out the rules and features of the game. Playtesting itself, however, poses an interesting set of challenges. Character sheets, copies of the rules, and other materials needed to properly test the system all have a monetary cost, which can be offset by this campaign. Of course, organizing times and putting in the effort to actually refine the game (rather than simply playing a broken system) are challenges in and of themselves, but most of our group has been playing tabletop games for years, if not decades, and we are uniquely suited to undertake this development not only because of that, but because of our blend of skills and education and training.
  • Finding illustrators and cartographers willing to join the project is obviously a challenge, that carries with it a set of risks - getting quality work in a timely fashion will never be inexpensive - and we hope to use a large portion of the funding to compensate such artists fairly. There is a long-standing saying that there are three categories of work: fast, cheap, and good, and you can only pick two. We hope to be able to get high quality artwork delivered quickly, but we know this will not come at a low rate of pay. The development team behind Apocalypse is well connected in both the online and local artistic communities, and so we have a variety of artists to approach, but we'll need help from this funding campaign to ensure that the artists are fairly compensated for their work.

Scheduling

  • We are launching this Indiegogo on May 7th, 2015. It will run until July 7th, ending on Cody's birthday. 
  •  We plan to work on procuring illustrators and cartographers and giving them design plans to work with, as well as finishing the current round of playtests and incorporating the new facets of the game that develop from these over the summer and fall of 2015. 
  • During the fall and winter of 2015, we will be hoping to ensure the proper write-ups and formatting of the setting, including all the towns and NPCs we've already made, those earned by contributors, some adventure plots, plot hooks, and campaigns that have already been tested (and exist, in note form), as well as developing new aspects of the setting. This, of course, is an ongoing and constant development now, but still has a lot of work to be done. 
  • During the spring of 2016, we hope to begin the first phases of publication and marketing, and we will be hoping to begin providing our contribution rewards in either spring or early summer of next year, as well.
This is a tight time-frame, but the contributions from this Indiegogo campaign will make it possible to devote a lot of our time and effort to these goals.

We hope not to have setbacks, but any setbacks, as well as regular progress updates, will be published on the Facebook and the blogs run by the development team. 

If you have any questions, comments, encouragement, or any other correspondence to offer, feel free to send an e-mail to our team  at apocalypsedevteam@gmail.com

In Summary

The goal of getting Apocalypse developmentally completed and published has been on the hearts and minds of all of Cody's gamer friends since before his untimely passing, and was even discussed at his funeral as a way to give proper homage to our brotherhood and friendship. Hopefully you, too, will be able to contribute to this goal and help us fund this undertaking.

If you are unable to contribute in these notably difficult times, the best way you can help is to raise awareness about the project itself. Share the campaign on Facebook and other social media, keep spreading awareness, and even use the awesome sharing tools that Indiegogo has to aid in keeping Apocalypse in the eyes of the gaming community.

Tell your friends and family, other gamers, and anyone you think may be interested. 

Inform them, before it's too late, that the Apocalypse is coming.
story_txt:
The Story Behind Apocalypse 
One
hundred years ago all hell broke loose, literally. Massive planar
gates appeared and hordes of what looked like angels and demons
poured through, to wage war on each other with humanity caught in the
middle...Mankind struggled greatly in the war. Angels used us
as demon fodder, while the demons enslaved us. Though in some ways we
had greater technology, physically we were weak in comparison. The
best scientists at Genetix Corp. began working on a mutagen to make
the common man into a juggernaut. Instead, what we got were diseased
humans with an inability to feel pain, an endless rage, and a taste
for flesh....With our armies decimated, and cities ravaged by
the sickness, the world leaders decided that if we can't win, no one
wins. Nuclear weapons were detonated in all the plagued cities, and
at all the planar gates. The war was over, and mankind clung to life
in a new world fraught with danger...In 2011, Cody Bellinger began the construction of a new tabletop RPG system - one focused on realistic play, exciting roleplaying, and gritty adventure - which he named Apocalypse. He began his work with influences from many other games and systems, including Dungeons and Dragons, Paranoia, and Fallout, but the first version of the product he unveiled was a creature entirely of his own making. With the help of his gaming circle, he began to revise and refine the system through discussion and playtesting, expanding it to a set of rules that could be used in a variety of ways in multiple settings.Unfortunately, tragedy struck in January 2013 as Cody unexpectedly passed away due to an aortic hemorrhage at only 23 years of age. The gaming group splintered due to the tragedy, and no progress was made on the game, with the pain of Cody's loss too near to the hearts of those who knew him.In April of 2015, knowing that Cody would want his game played, one of the regular gamemasters of the previous group took the effort to recover Cody's documentation and begin his work again, discussing the rules and settings not only with the previous gaming group, but with a new group that had grown in the intervening years, and restarted playtesting. Combining the documents that Cody had already constructed with notes and thoughts shared through private messaging prior to Cody's untimely death, refinement and development began anew.With permission from Cody's mother (who, in her own right, has always acted as Group Mom for this myriad group of 20-somethings), we hope to complete the production of Apocalypse and the publication of the new system, both as a memorial to Cody's work and a fresh new take on d20 tabletop gaming for the gaming community. Now we just need your help to make this project of Cody's into a legacy. 



The Impact
Apocalypse is a d20 game, but it's unlike any other popular d20 game currently on the market. While it contains elements of this staple of tabletopping that will be familiar to many in the community, it not only brings a fresh, new setting into ready availability, but is designed around real-world actions, effects, and consequences.Apocalypse is played in the post-apocalyptic world following the events described above, and as such, is a challenging, exciting, and potentially lethal system. Whether you're dealing with shotgun-toting raiders in trucks or you're going toe to toe with a demon behemoth, every choice has the potential to bring dire consequences or great rewards. With a new approach to weapon, armor, and character design mechanics comes a laundry list of potential combinations of randomized mutations, class-based powers, and unique abilities. Even the landscape can prove dangerous, as radiation effects and environmental shifts due to the apocalypse can surprise even the most careful adventurers.Apocalypse mechanics use  a logical, real-world approach to armor functionality (lessening and abating damage received rather than simply making a character harder to hit), weaponry (do you want the shotgun, or the missile launcher?), vehicles, basic equipment, and more. 
This kind of ingenuity of design is not limited just to the setting, The basic rules of the system and its integral workings bring a new perspective into tabletop RPGs, with aspects of the system designed to make actions, story, and even equipment and gear not only more logical, but easier to work with, easier for beginners to understand, and more realistic, allowing for deeper immersion and abundant excitement for players. The flexibility of the system itself also allows for more creative actions, allowing players to be simplistic and straightforward, or even take inspiration from action movie heroes and tropes.The storyline is well-developed and its seamless integration with the system allows for players to build their own style of play without being disruptive, whether they're focused mainly on the combat aspects and mechanics of the game or on the roleplaying aspects of tabletop gaming.
Apocalypse is the new tabletop that the gaming community needs, and will provide hours, days, or even years of fun to its players.

What Makes Apocalypse Different?There are a lot of facets that make Apocalypse revolutionary when it comes to tabletop gaming. Obviously, we'd like to keep some of those things back for release so that people who acquire a set of books post-publication (either through a donation perk or through purchase) will have new discoveries to make, but here are some of the awesome parts of what sets Apocalypse apart:
Apocalypse has a well-developed, in-depth setting. It contains fully fleshed out stories, NPCs with years of background, and an explanation for anything and everything the players may encounter - but the things the players encounter are varied, story-rich, and detailed.
The setting is also highly immersive. While other games give you cool abilities, strange powers, and world-shaking items, Apocalypse is driven on making you feel these things are plausible. Through simplicity and the reality-based design of the mechanics and setting, Apocalypse doesn't have the issue of many other tabletop games where the abilities seem too far-fetched for player grasp and comprehension. Players could even start the game as literal copies of themselves, if they really wished. However, powers and abilities are still fantastical, adventurous, and powerful enough to make the game fun.
Another major facet of the Apocalypse system is that it's highly adaptable. Whether the concern is with adaptability to GM designs, player-created situations, or even other setting designs, the system is designed in a way to allow it to be catered to anyone's preferences.
Similarly to the system itself, classes and abilities are highly customizable. There is no “best build,” or preferred class design. All of the characters are unique, and even part of the system is designed to ensure this, as character mutations are acquired through random rolls by the GM.
Mutations themselves are a definite point of interest, because Apocalypse has a list of possible mutations rivaling comic book worlds, but all are designed in such a way to be useful and usable in the game, and the mechanics allow them to function in highly plausible ways.
The fact is, Apocalypse is meant to be played much like an action movie. From shoving a shotgun down a demon's throat, to playing hot potato with a live semtex grenade, the system is built to handle any creative playing idea that players come up with, or that a GM wants to throw in.

These are just a few of the unique aspects that set Apocalypse apart, and hopefully they're attractive features for potential users. People who wish to keep up with some of the more detailed aspects of the system's construction and development are also free to follow the Apocalypse team Facebook, Twitter, and Tumblr blog.


What We Need & What You Get While $50,000 may seem like a lofty goal, we have some pretty big plans to make Apocalypse into what Cody originally envisioned. We hope to produce and publish a full-length, hardback Apocalypse Core Book on a wide scale, complete with illustrations, information about the rules, the methods of play, the classes, and a full exposition of the factions, settings, and ongoing events of the world of Apocalypse. If we exceed that goal, we'll even begin working on supplemental materials immediately.  A major part of our planned budget is for illustrations, both sketched and fully detailed color images. With around 120 images planned, this part of our budget is roughly $15,000.
Another important aspect of a core rulebook is the cartography. From setting topography and cityscapes to detailed graphs and dungeons, maps are an integral component of any good tabletop RPG. We plan to hire the best cartographer(s) we can afford, to add these important elements. This part of our budget is also set at $15,000.
Of course, publication is a major aspect of our plan for Apocalypse. We hope to self-publish through a respectable publishing agency that focuses on game publication. To that end, we have set aside $5,000 in our budget based on our research into publishers and the packages offered by the company we hope to engage. 
Writing and editing costs are not inexpensive, and while Cody began fleshing out the setting, there is still much to be done. Part of the production team is already made up of freelance writers and editors, and so we hope to gain their full focus on this project - but that comes at the expense of any other projects which they might otherwise undertake. We hope to use $5,000 to $10,000 to fairly compensate them for their time and efforts exclusively on this project, as well as the time and efforts of the R&D team and designers. The remaining $5,000 to $10,000 of the original $50,000 goal will be used to trademark and copyright the Apocalypse game, setting and related materials, as well as being used for marketing beyond the original marketing materials granted by the publication company's package. Any remainder will be used to offset the cost of playtesting, including the printing of pre-publication manuscripts and materials, project-specific transportation costs, and other assorted project-specific costs.
 
That's how our plan for the money usage breaks down, but we also plan to provide our contributors with some fun perks for contributions.  Contributors of various levels can get the following awesome rewards:




An NPC designed according to your specifications (within the game rules) and placed permanently in the setting of Apocalypse.
A hardback copy of the Apocalypse Core Book from the first edition printing, signed by the development leads (even including a copy of Cody's signature).
An unsigned hardback copy of the Apocalypse Core Book 
A 36" x 24" laminated color poster of the Apocalypse Core Setting map.

A Township in the Apocalypse Core Setting named according to either your name or your choice of name (within the reasonable confines of the setting).
Your name in the Design Motivators section of the Apocalypse Core Book credits.

A PDF copy of the Apocalypse Core Book.
Your name in the Contributors section of the Apocalypse Core Book credits.
Your name in the Special Thanks section of the Apocalypse Core Book credits.


We also have plans in place for Stretch Goals and new Perks for Stretch Goal Completion, which we will unveil at appropriate times during the campaign.




    Risks & Challenges With any ongoing project, there are natural challenges and obstacles to overcome, and in this aspect, Apocalypse is no different.


The fact is, Apocalypse is a d20 system. There are many others, and one of the challenges we hope to overcome with the help of this campaign is that Apocalypse is being birthed into a field of competition with long-established systems of other types. We hope to use part of the money raised by this campaign, as mentioned, to aid in marketing both pre- and post-publication.

In the same vein, exposure is a major factor. Part of the reason our publication budget is so high (and may even end up taking a larger portion of the funds than we've already planned) is because we want to make sure that we start out with enough copies of the first edition of the Apocalypse Core Book to have a decently wide original distribution base.
While Cody designed something great in the Apocalypse system, he wasn't the best at organizing and fully updating his material. It has already taken countless hours and multiple people working very hard to re-organize the things that he left us, as well as incorporating the various private messages, notes, and random memories we have from gaming sessions into the rules and setting. This effort will be constant and ongoing, and poses a difficult challenge to all the designers and writers. This challenge and the time and effort to overcome it will be aided not only by the fact that we have several professional writers in the development team, but also they will be able to devote more time and effort if they are not sacrificing income to do so through payment from the campaign.

Playtesting is an important aspect of the development process. From its inception, Apocalypse has been best refined by playing short campaigns and game sessions to test out the rules and features of the game. Playtesting itself, however, poses an interesting set of challenges. Character sheets, copies of the rules, and other materials needed to properly test the system all have a monetary cost, which can be offset by this campaign. Of course, organizing times and putting in the effort to actually refine the game (rather than simply playing a broken system) are challenges in and of themselves, but most of our group has been playing tabletop games for years, if not decades, and we are uniquely suited to undertake this development not only because of that, but because of our blend of skills and education and training.
Finding illustrators and cartographers willing to join the project is obviously a challenge, that carries with it a set of risks - getting quality work in a timely fashion will never be inexpensive - and we hope to use a large portion of the funding to compensate such artists fairly. There is a long-standing saying that there are three categories of work: fast, cheap, and good, and you can only pick two. We hope to be able to get high quality artwork delivered quickly, but we know this will not come at a low rate of pay. The development team behind Apocalypse is well connected in both the online and local artistic communities, and so we have a variety of artists to approach, but we'll need help from this funding campaign to ensure that the artists are fairly compensated for their work.




Scheduling


We are launching this Indiegogo on May 7th, 2015. It will run until July 7th, ending on Cody's birthday. 


 We plan to work on procuring illustrators and cartographers and giving them design plans to work with, as well as finishing the current round of playtests and incorporating the new facets of the game that develop from these over the summer and fall of 2015. 


During the fall and winter of 2015, we will be hoping to ensure the proper write-ups and formatting of the setting, including all the towns and NPCs we've already made, those earned by contributors, some adventure plots, plot hooks, and campaigns that have already been tested (and exist, in note form), as well as developing new aspects of the setting. This, of course, is an ongoing and constant development now, but still has a lot of work to be done. 


During the spring of 2016, we hope to begin the first phases of publication and marketing, and we will be hoping to begin providing our contribution rewards in either spring or early summer of next year, as well.


This is a tight time-frame, but the contributions from this Indiegogo campaign will make it possible to devote a lot of our time and effort to these goals.We hope not to have setbacks, but any setbacks, as well as regular progress updates, will be published on the Facebook and the blogs run by the development team. If you have any questions, comments, encouragement, or any other correspondence to offer, feel free to send an e-mail to our team  at apocalypsedevteam@gmail.com    In Summary The goal of getting Apocalypse developmentally completed and published has been on the hearts and minds of all of Cody's gamer friends since before his untimely passing, and was even discussed at his funeral as a way to give proper homage to our brotherhood and friendship.
